We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts: Living in a sprawling city means my neighborhood is incredibly diverse. Residential areas are randomly spread out between commercial zones where a wide range of businesses operate. Offices, various stores, and entertainment venues are all present. With no shortage of new eateries or shopping spots, big-name corporate stores and small boutiques line the streets, sometimes within walking distance of quieter neighborhoods. Two nearby parks draw in many families with young children. Diversity also extends to the people living here. We have a notable LGBTQ+ community, Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees from the former Soviet Union, all in a small area. Venturing a bit further, the city is home to various racial and ethnic enclaves like Korea town, China town, and Little Armenia. While some areas are ethnically distinct, they are often just a few miles away, but driving a mere 10 miles can take up to two hours due to heavy traffic, especially during peak hours. Public transportation isn't heavily used, and traffic congestion is notorious. Despite recent construction of new apartment buildings, many residents are unhappy about the influx of more residents and vehicles. Housing options are diverse, ranging from single-family homes to duplexes and small apartment buildings. My neighborhood reflects this diversity, with people of different ages. I'm not familiar with most of my neighbors, unlike my childhood where I played with my next-door neighbor and a few close friends.

My neighborhood's got a unique blend of homes. Most are single family, but some are split into two, still attached, if you can picture it. My place has a small yard out front and a driveway to the left. It's like a throwback to a time when living in the suburbs was the American dream, and many neighborhoods like mine still hold onto that dream. The folks here aren't as optimistic as they used to be, and yard maintenance isn't what it once was, but there's still a car or two in every drive. Kids still play like the world's their playground, stopping only to let cars pass. The old public school, nearly 90 years young, still stands, inspiring today's youth while evoking nostalgia in the elders. Churches are few and far between, often empty, but the basketball courts are always full. Every house looks unique, yet feels the same. There's a large supermarket called Super "A," owned by a Yemeni family, possibly the only Arab family around. The majority of residents are African American. Kids play football on the wide streets, and most people have been here for generations, with many tales to tell of a past where everyone knew everyone. A karate school turned pharmacy, because drugs supposedly fix everything. There's an old movie theater playing classic films at a discount, preferred by the elders despite the youths' disdain for its lack of new releases. A single expressway runs through our town, with exits and entrances in the next town over. There was a petition to bring an exit to our town, with the youth supporting it, but the elders, fearing it would ruin the town, convinced the city council to deny the request. They're building a new high school, and we're trying to decide on a mascot for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would best represent our town.

You might initially overlook it - after all, it's located behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live, or at least not the kind of places most people would want to call home. But if you venture behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk past the hotels that only come to life during family reunions or summers, you'll discover an entire thriving community. Hidden within these streets are several apartment complexes - arranged side by side like carefully dismantled Russian nesting dolls, lined up along the road. The first complex you encounter has been in the news for some questionable activities, so we won't dwell too much on those - appearances can be deceiving. However, the complexes next to it and beyond are a world of their own, mostly unknown to the locals. Across from these complexes stands a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings where students saunter in with coffee cups in hand, yawning as they start their sleepy mornings. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while drivers honk and groan at them for holding up traffic on days with higher attendance. The road intersects with another residential street, complete with a park and a rehab center for individuals with bone injuries. The treatment center has cheerful porch furniture and a lazily spinning ceiling fan, stirring the warm summer air. Children play and cartwheel in the grass, while bees lazily buzz around the flower beds by the road. Retired folks stroll their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenage skateboarders and nodding to the girls clustered by the playground, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube trends. A sushi place in the strip mall beside the park offers affordable meals but is never too bustling - a swimming supply store lies next door, and a nail salon is tucked in between. You could fill your pool, get a manicure, and enjoy hibachi chicken all at once - the convenience of a strip mall. A frozen yogurt shop also resides there, where teens often grab DIY frozen yogurt cups with toppings while performing tricks on their skateboards and enjoying vapes. The neighborhood is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the languid south where change is rare, and even time seems to move slowly.

“Where is everything?” she asked as we cruised past the endless corn fields stretching out before us. “This is it!” I declared, knowing she'd be blown away by the vastness of the open countryside. She hailed from a bustling town where the grocery store was just five minutes' walk from her doorstep—she'd never seen so much empty space in her life. Taken aback by the omnipresence of corn fields, I shared with her what growing up in rural Ohio was like, and in that instant, she finally understood where I came from. Driving down a winding two-lane country road, you'll eventually reach a quarry brimming with water. Just past that you'll find the small development where I reside. The houses are mostly made of brick and stucco, each with at least a half-acre of land, which everyone takes great pride in maintaining. Springtime brings an abundance of annually planted flowers and the vibrant colors of midwestern trees that change with every season. Driveways are filled with gleaming Mercedes-Benz luxury cars after a good car wash. Continuing down the road towards my grey stucco home, I have a Korean neighbor who's always out and about. He spends his days mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over the hum of his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Everyone finds him amusing, but he's genuinely nice and has a remarkable past as a doctor. These days, he blends with the lawn and his mower, losing some of his wit with age. Finally, you'll reach my home. In the side yard, geese are aplenty and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, a small stream feeds into the quarry. Here, you'll hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with wild-growing trees, herbs, and flowers. This was my childhood playground. We built tree forts, played pretend, and chased animals—well, mostly chased each other. The winters in my small town can be mercilessly cold, yet there's nothing more enchanting. The yard transforms from a lush green expanse into a wintry wonderland. The vibrant fall foliage turns into stark, bare branches and the occasional snowfall creates a magical winter wonderland. The backyard is filled with snow angels and snowmen my sister and I made. We fought like siblings, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapons of choice. We'd build massive igloo-like forts to house our arsenal, using branches as makeshift weapons. Our little winter wonderland was where our imaginations ran wild and nothing else mattered. We were just young kids, carefree and innocent.

The first thing you should know about Portland, Oregon is that it's definitely "weird". The tongue-in-cheek town motto, plastered on the back of a building that doubles as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, and a place that flirts with the law on most of its enterprises, is "Keep Portland Weird". For some, this is a reminder of the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less well-known and less pricey, fostering creative and unique subcultures. For others, it's an invitation - come to Portland, where being weird is seen as a badge of honor. Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the non-stop construction of condos, Portland remains weird. Being weird isn't about accepting everything, but it is about accepting the unusual. It doesn't mean we lack modern conveniences or face the same issues as the rest of the country. Like everyone else, we buy a lot from China. Weirdness comes in countless forms, and Portland has plenty of "normal" too - yoga, hipsters, business professionals. Perhaps weirdness is just a matter of taking it all less seriously. In my neighborhood, and many other Portland neighborhoods, you'll find colorful houses, gardens with flowers, herbs, and vegetables, and free boxes in the summer. These free boxes are usually cardboard containing items someone's getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They hold magical treasures, perfect for the passerby, often enough. Free boxes often contain clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of wandering through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about - to me, at least, but I'm just one of the many different weirdos here. Some people I live among would never dream of picking clothes from a sidewalk box. They'd rather go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is filled with people who love all sorts of things. Many dream about pursuing their dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug issues are often rooted in mental health struggles, and the constant rain and dreary clouds can exacerbate this. Portland also has a homelessness problem, which no one seems to know how to fix. Our social services are better than in many places, but they're still not enough. The local population swings between care and resentment. In this, Portland is not weird at all.

The mountains have always been there, looming over the north, constantly witnessing the sun's daily journey. Even when I'm caught up in work or life, they stand firm, unyielding and unaffected by life's challenges. On days when stress and worry overwhelm me, they call out to me, offering solace and strength when I turn to them. I first noticed them when I moved here for my undergrad, and they've been captivating me ever since. While the university and town have their own charms, it's the mountains that hold a special place in my heart. The town, with its blend of urban and suburban life, offers a unique atmosphere. There are countless cafes where I've spent many hours studying, and the downtown area, with its vintage brick buildings, has a bustling energy that's almost magical. Just beyond the library, you can find a serene, small-town vibe. This mix of environments creates a wonderful cityscape, beckoning exploration. Each part of town holds cherished memories for me - from late-night walks with friends to catching movies in a fancy theater. But it also holds harsh memories, as all places do. The ponds, especially, have been a place for deep reflection and late-night existential crises. Watching the pond creatures live their lives has made me ponder my own purpose in life. I've walked past the park and houses, until I reached the main street. There, the sun painted the sky with its brilliant rays, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was heading north. And there they were, as always - the strong, imposing mountains painting the sky, giving me the strength to carry on, one day at a time.

If you're thinking of dropping by Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, don't worry, it's super accessible! Public transport is a breeze, which is a big plus in NYC. Bensonhurt is a bit of an urban jungle, so you'll still feel like you're in the city. Be ready to spot plenty of Asian stores around. Over the past couple of decades, Bensonhurt has seen a surge of Asian residents, which means you'll find at least one Asian-owned business every block. Supermarkets and laundromats are the most common, and locals love them because the food quality is top-notch, prices are cheap, and they're super convenient. I've got four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of my place! Not that Bensonhurt is all Asian, though; it's incredibly diverse. Most big local businesses are Asian-owned, but there's also a newly renovated park nearby with plenty of courts for all sorts of sports, playgrounds, and a water fountain. NYC parks are always diverse and welcoming. There aren't many big corporate buildings; mostly you'll find co-op living or condo apartments, with the majority of homes being two-family houses. Most people are friendly, but it can get noisy, with cars blasting music and people revving their engines all the time. Be cautious at night; the neighborhood is generally safe, but people can be unpredictable, and you might encounter bullies and thieves. I've had my share of trouble here, like being physically assaulted years ago and having packages stolen. Package theft is common, and there's also a lot of dog waste around. It's my biggest pet peeve! Just be careful and keep your shoes clean!

Where I live, sidewalks are a scarcity. The streets slope downwards, and my home sits at the highest point of the steepest hill in the neighborhood, earning it the nickname "workout hill" for the joggers who pound the pavement daily. With no sidewalks on my street, everyone walks in the road. The surfaces are rough in places, making it a bit treacherous to drive on. The telecommunication and electric lines overhead are a tattered mess, constantly being repaired due to regular rain and storms. Trees, especially evergreens, are everywhere, but locals detest them for obstructing the ocean view. Houses are built high up on the hill, with expansive glass-fronted second stories lining the crest, all vying for a glimpse of the bay. Sunsets are breathtaking when the water is illuminated from below and the sky turns orange, but clouds often obscure the view, and moss grows on everything, even my car. Kids are rare, and dogs and rabbits are more common. There are no stores nearby, but a short hike down to the waterfront leads to a few restaurants serving fresh seafood. The bay is not wide, but the rocks along the shore are fun to toss into the water, and you can see the opposite shore on clear days.

I reside in a typical suburban area of a small southern town in Tennessee, nestled between two state highways which brings a bit more traffic than I'd ideally prefer. However, aside from that, it’s a quiet locale. Not many folks move in or out, so I've become accustomed to the folks who live in the neighborhood. Most people keep busy with yard work and daily chores, while others enjoy walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids zip around on their bikes as you'd expect. My family and I are often at home since we work from our house; my wife and I, along with our daughters, ages eleven and fourteen, are a familiar sight to the neighborhood. We engage in outdoor activities, even in the rain, and occasionally we grill outside on our back deck, filling the air with the pleasant aroma of barbecue. Lawn mowers are a common sound from March through October, as neighbors keep their grass trimmed. The neighborhood is shaded by trees, which were originally part of a wooded area, but that also means dealing with leaves in the fall, which we rake and burn annually. I find the smell of burning leaves a comforting sign that fall has arrived. Lately, we've had little winter, making it seem like a prolonged fall. Our garage is at the back, so we don't use the front door much unless someone knocks, which is rare. I enjoy working in the garage on my truck or other projects, as it makes me feel more connected to the neighborhood. Holidays are quite quiet here, but during Thanksgiving, Mother's Day, and Christmas, you’ll see extra cars parked as neighbors visit with out-of-town family. Overall, I enjoy living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.

My neighborhood is smack dab in the high desert, where dirt is the reigning color. Unless you've been here, you might not understand the feeling of constant brown. When you do see a lawn, you know that person is investing a fortune in its upkeep. Back in the 90s, houses were scattered far and wide. Now, the layout is similar, but new additions are popping up. Truth is, this place is starting to look more and more like a city, and I suppose that's how it goes everywhere. Most people here are friendly, but just like any city, there are good areas and not-so-good ones. In my neighborhood, I'm surrounded by friendly old folks—it's quite nice. The stores here are mostly chain places like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. If you're looking for upscale, you'll have to travel. I don't often see stores like Whole Foods around here.

Most prominent jobs in my city, based on my observations, are in construction. I think it's because this place is still developing, with a lot of room for building. That bothers me a bit; I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and don't want to go back. Speaking of construction, that's what my full-time job is about—drywall and T-bar installation.

What I love about my home is the variety of animals. People come here for the desert's stark beauty, and the climate and topography create unique ecosystems that need protection and are home to diverse wildlife. My family and I have gotten used to the wildlife. My three kids are obsessed with lizards and desert bugs; they're outside now trying to catch some specimens.

As for attractions, Victorville offers some unique experiences. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with the San Bernardino County Fair. It's a great time to experience Victorville's way of life. You could also head to nearby Wrightwood to see snow-covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons. If you're interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert, the Victor Valley Museum is a must-visit. It houses geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's development.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'd say it's a bit different from the typical image most people have. Instead of your traditional residential area with homeowners leading their individual lives, my neighborhood is the college campus where I live. The people who live in my dormitory make up my community, and the surrounding campus also contributes to this feeling of neighborhood, though to a lesser degree. Despite this uniqueness, my neighborhood shares some standard features with other neighborhoods. It, too, includes houses, people, stores, and parks. Let's start by talking about the "houses" in my neighborhood. To understand my neighborhood's housing, it's important to know the types of houses that populate it. There are three main types of housing: apartments, actual houses, and dormitory houses. In the apartments, each room usually houses 2-4 people, with about 4-6 rooms on each floor. A building can hold around 20 people on average. Actual houses are scattered throughout the neighborhood and are typically rented by school affiliates, usually alumni. These houses are usually 2-4 bedrooms. Dormitory houses are by far the most common, accommodating hundreds of students. In these, you'll find two people sharing a room, with the exception of a few. Now, let's move on to the people. My college prides itself on diversity, and this is evident in the makeup of my neighborhood. The diverse cultures and ages that live here are one of the things that make it special. Professional staff members tend to live in the houses available for rent, while newer students stay in dormitory-style housing, and older students live in apartments. To talk about the people in my neighborhood would take too long, so let's move on to the stores and parks. Since my school is self-contained, it offers a variety of stores, including dining options and the school's unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. This means that everything needed can be found within my neighborhood's boundaries. Additionally, my neighborhood has a park that serves as a playground for all the diverse people who live here. This park is kept clean and safe by everyone in the community!

Well, having spent a decade here, I can share some of my experiences. When I first arrived in this neighborhood, I was quite down because I was leaving behind the familiarity of Riverdale for Stockbridge. I cried, as much as I loved my old home and friends, but my parents wanted a better environment for us. The move to a more upmarket neighborhood was a significant change, but it came with its benefits, like a better high school and less “ghetto” surroundings. Over time, I adjusted, made new friends, and even some enemies. I got to know a few neighbors well, like Mr. Glen and his family, and Dennis. They’ve become like family to me, and I deeply appreciate their presence.

One memorable moment was attending Mr. Glen and Ms. Veda's wedding – a joyful event where I caught the wedding bouquet's garter but missed the flowers! We danced and had a great time, especially with their daughter, Marsharii. I haven’t seen her since, but I hope she’s doing well.

The neighborhood is a bit like a maze, but I have a GPS to guide me through. I’ve explored only a little, mainly with Kason and Curtis. We used to enjoy video games and nature walks, which somehow soothe my soul. I also enjoy practicing my balance with sticks from Home Depot and, if I can, my bokken wooden sword. The basketball and tennis courts are there if I ever want to pick up those sports again. My dad and best friend used to train with Mr. Graves in tennis, and it was always a fun, challenging experience. There are plenty of enjoyable memories here, and I’m sure many more are yet to come!

My neighborhood is conveniently close to my college, which is why I appreciate living here. There's mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars nearby that aren't too pricey. One of the bars just changed its name and is a bit pricier, but the service and drinks aren't bad. Most people are friendly, with many being college students or lower income due to affordable housing. A nearby elementary school means there are a lot of kids around. I don't know my neighbors, and that's fine by me. They smoke a lot of weed, which led to the building's management placing an air freshener unit near their door. I think it's funny, but also slightly insulting. The buildings here are usually old but might have nice interiors. Down the street, there are newer apartments, but I think they're cheaply built. Their rent is high, but they're near campus, so management can charge more. There's a cheap restaurant around five minutes away that uses paper plates and microwaves most of its food. Across from it is a gas station I've heard isn't great to work at. The area has improved with road repairs from the city, adding a nice sidewalk, grass, and a nicer look. Behind my apartment complex, there's a tree line and another set of apartments. I live on 42nd Street, and just behind it is 43rd Street, which isn't as nice. The sidewalks are poor quality and buildings look rundown, with many trees to hide their condition. Crime has occurred at apartment complexes on 43rd Street, but I can't blame them alone. Across the street from me, there's also a problematic apartment building with a transient population. Despite this, I like living here. It's affordable, and I have easy access to useful amenities like the university and two bus stops. I can get to the store and downtown with ease.

My neighborhood is a peaceful cul-de-sac filled with yellow duplexes, each with white porches and green metal roofs. We're tucked away from the hustle of the modern world, with fields and trees surrounding us, and blue skies dotted with white clouds. It's a bit like stepping back in time, with almost everyone being friends with each other. On some evenings, we gather at the end of the driveway, chatting as the kids play. Last night, we faced a unique challenge: a tornado warning and actual sirens. I huddled in the bathtub with my little dog and a few pillows, while my bigger dog stayed in the living room, nervous and barking. The neighborhood was eerily quiet, save for the sound of large hail hitting the ground. After the storm, the road was steaming from the temperature change, and the hail melted immediately on the hot pavement. A double rainbow appeared, and I snapped pictures to share with friends and family. The streets remained quiet for a while, and then it was back to business as usual. I love this community, especially the southern accents, having moved from NH to NC. I live in a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment, as do most of my neighbors. Despite the houses looking alike, the interiors vary. I enjoy walking to the nearby pond, where I've seen deer and heard bullfrogs in the morning. It's a fantastic place to live, just forty minutes from Charlotte. Each morning is greeted by roosters crowing from the nearby farms. There's even a donkey at a nearby farm that lets us know he's there with his evening braying. I consider myself lucky to have found this cozy neighborhood.

I moved to this neighborhood just as I was about to start eighth grade. Making friends initially was tough, but I eventually became close with someone who lived two houses down and another guy on my street. They've since moved away, but the memories remain. Most of the original residents are still here, and my neighborhood is typical of any American suburban area. It's filled with two-story houses, and on warm weekends or nice days, you can hear kids playing outside. The neighborhood is usually quiet, and I've never had issues with any neighbors. I trust them, and I've never had any trouble with packages being stolen from my porch. The park a couple of minutes away from my house is where I've spent countless hours. I've played basketball, football, and baseball with the neighborhood kids, and although I have one bad memory from getting elbowed in the nose playing football, the good times outweigh the bad. Now, I often visit the park to spend time with my cousin's kids who enjoy playing on the swings and slides. The park evokes nostalgic feelings, as it's where I made many of my childhood memories. The neighborhood is diverse, with a variety of food options nearby, including Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants, all accessible via delivery apps like GrubHub and DoorDash. There's a Walgreens, a CVS, and a Jewel-Osco grocery store on the same street, along with a diverse range of stores, including an Indian-owned shop. Overall, I'm grateful for my neighborhood as it's a safe and comfortable place to live, unlike some of the horror stories I've seen on news and social media.

My neighborhood, Johnston, is a charming little town nestled in South Carolina. Like many others in the region, it doesn't exactly stand out, but it's a significant player in the agricultural scene. The town is famously known as the Peach Capital of the World, a title proudly displayed on the welcoming sign. The landscape is dominated by vast farmlands, either filled with peach trees or cattle. Houses are scattered, usually two stories high with metal roofs to beat the summer heat or gray shingles for a traditional look. Most homes are tucked back from the road, allowing the front fields to serve as pastures for animals or crops. In the main town area, there's a single stop sign at a four-way intersection where all the stores are located. You can grab "fast food" from Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's burger joint. A former pizzeria has since closed down. Maxwell and Halford Drug, a family-owned pharmacy, is famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola. The Independent Grocers Alliance, or IGA, is the only grocery store, though most residents prefer to shop at a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville. The Dollar General is the busiest store in town, offering a wide range of everyday items. Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman, has been a town staple for years and offers furniture delivery. Attached to the furniture store is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet grooming service offering a variety of pet care services. Both a doctor's practice and a veterinary clinic are located away from the main town area, but they are well-equipped to serve the residents. Johnston Elementary School is the only school in town, with students transferring to the next town for middle and high school. There are no parks, but a 2.5-acre recreational area is being developed. The town is so small that you could breeze through it without noticing, but it's quite cozy nevertheless!

The first time I learned about my place, I caught a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was quite surprising. The rent for almost every apartment nearby was over a grand a month. I'd never heard a whisper about it, and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the harsh reality. I know a few of my buddies are so stressed out they cry themselves to sleep over the costs. Things are expensive, but we've managed to be thrifty over the years. You start to appreciate the nostalgic smell of flea market toys and second-hand clothes. You smell less in adulthood. You might pick up the habit of smoking, or you might just be used to the state of things. But the flea market always finds its way in. The scent of adulthood lingers in the dusty magazines on a closed piano and clings to the leather, even after washing. Here, within walking distance, there are three thrift stores. If you start from the edge, you can pop into two charity shops, a library, a rare bookstore, and a curio shop. Downtown is bustling, cars and people fill the streets daily, but you'll never hear it inside the thrifts. Not a soul nor a sound from the outside world can penetrate the silent stores. It's a great place to lose an afternoon. Each year, the city grows denser with people and cars. They claim it's a developing city, with an online empire headquartered here for e-commerce and delivery. It's still showing signs of growth pains, much like New York. Everyone's focused on their own goals, and they don't ask much from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a bit concerned means you genuinely care. You don't pry into anyone's life here. You can keep your shell as long as you want, and the city will just roll along like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to call home. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always some sort of music or action. We're not just a bunch of strangers in an apartment building; we're a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate life's milestones, and help each other when possible. In a way, I feel lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors, and they treat me well. I make sure to tidy up after myself and leave them some food, and they do the same for me. We share mail, and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl, but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't make a mistake in choosing to live here.

My neighborhood is your typical cookie cutter suburbia, but with a unique twist. The homeowner's association is very strict here, which means every house is well-maintained and uniform. There are no individual mailboxes; instead, there's a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street, and two larger lockers for packages. The houses are mostly single-story, but you'll find a mix of both. The neighborhood is located on the edge of a nearby city, making it partially rural and partially suburban. There's plenty of land, including community pools and walking trails, so you can get your exercise right in your neighborhood. It's mainly inhabited by retired folks and a small mix of middle-aged and young professionals. The city itself is surprisingly large in population but retains a small-town feel. There's a single mall for shopping, and it's a 15-minute drive to get there. It offers everything from high-end grocery stores to bargain outlets. Overall, it's a safe, well-maintained neighborhood with a lot of nice amenities like pools and walking trails. Although we're not right next door to major shopping, you can easily hop in a car and get to any major chain you'd like.

I reside in a small Midwestern town situated just on the outskirts of a major city's suburban areas. My immediate neighborhood, located on the east side of town, is recognized as the most economically disadvantaged part of the town. Property values are generally lower, with most houses being either rented to or owned by individuals with lower incomes. Despite this, the area is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are typically friendly and will often greet me with a smile as I walk down the street. While crime rates are slightly higher compared to other parts of town, they are still low. Over the past decade, there have been a few violent incidents, including shootings and a homicide, within a few blocks of my home. Our next-door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside a nearby bar last year. Thankfully, our family has not been directly impacted by crime beyond the occasional item disappearing from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. The town I live in has been significantly affected by the ongoing "opioid epidemic" that has impacted many parts of the United States. Unfortunately, many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are numerous resources available in our town to combat this issue, including addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, the town has many positive aspects. My son's elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. My son, despite having special needs, has not faced any bullying due to the school's incredibly positive atmosphere and loves it there. We have an active PTO that organizes multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town's population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, ensuring that no child ever goes hungry. No child or family is treated as "less than" due to their inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Most of these improvements have been concentrated in the town center and on the west side, where all the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side, where I live, often feels neglected, which is a point of contention for my neighbors. Overall, I enjoy living in this town. The people are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options to meet my family's needs, and while our home may not be worth much, it is comfortable and adequate. We have lived here for over 16 years and cannot envision living anywhere else.

My neighborhood is rich in culture. It's situated on a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical significance. I reside in a 7-story apartment building right across from the old live Theatre, and a block down from The Hill is a quaint arcade bar that draws diverse crowds on warm summer nights. On weekends in June and July, you often see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park, quite large for its location. Surrounding the park is concrete, with tall steps poured into the wall. During winter, homeless people set up their tents in neat rows, using the central location to stay warmer despite the lack of snow and the cold rain. They're also close to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city, though, isn't the historic buildings or the architecture scattered across the rolling hills leading to the ocean. What I love is the culture of the people themselves. Hilltop was once notorious for gang violence, and even today, stories about the federal government and DEA efforts to clean the streets are passed down from generation to generation. Despite it being considered one of the roughest neighborhoods, the people here work hard to keep it clean. They still care about what happens in their city and on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark, a warning that feels like a remnant of the past, tainted by social conditioning. Maybe it's that I'm dark enough to pass as less white, or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who understands the reminders of racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions made out of ignorance and fear. No matter where I go, Hilltop feels like home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have offered me a jacket or a kind word more than they would rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners stay open a few extra minutes for me to charge my phone when I have nowhere else to escape the rain. It's a place where I've sat, feeling invisible, huddled against concrete storefronts on the greyest nights, only to have someone stop, look me in the eye, and hand me $5, telling me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I hail from rural America, nestled within the small, picturesque town of Michigan. My locale is a delightful blend of farmland and tourist havens, with no big city malls, Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s in sight. You've got to drive to get anywhere, but the beauty is unparalleled. Lake Michigan and Lake Charlevoix flank the town, offering a serene coastline and inviting beaches. My neighborhood embodies the quintessential small-town vibe. Houses aren't stacked or cookie-cutter; they're older, with some having been updated, and many sporting full basements visible from the road. Aluminum siding and a rainbow of colors adorn the homes, each with yards featuring trampolines, play areas, gardens, and fences for pets. Middle America is epitomized here, with hardworking families raising or having raised their kids. Kids darting up and down the streets, and neighbors walking dogs, biking, and rollerblading are common sights. You recognize who fits in and who doesn't. Neighbors wave and smile, with lawns well-maintained and free of fall leaves. Our town is not flashy but safe and inviting, representing what people seek in life—a peaceful haven. The county sheriff’s department and jail are nearby, along with the health department, city recycling center, baseball and softball fields, and a small airport. You can hear planes taking off and landing while enjoying ice cream from the local shop or riding bikes to the park. My kids can even ride their bikes downtown. It's truly a great place to call home.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street and that one isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that is probably to hide what the buildings look like. Most of the crime in my area has happened at an apartment complex on that street, but then again, I can’t blame just them. There are apartments across the street from me that also have a lot of crime and a rather transient population. But I think I like where I live. I can afford it, and there’s plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially like how the university is within walking distance and there are two bus stops so that I can get to the store and downtown with ease.
My neighborhood is made up of duplex's on a cul-de-sac. They are intermittently placed and spaced so that they look like individual houses. The only difference is each is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone, but not all, are friends with each other. We stand at the end of a not pre-decided driveway some evenings and chit chat while the small children of the neighborhood play with their toys, sidewalk chalk or fly their kites. It is very refreshing in this modern all to mechanical/computer filled world. It is rather like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees enhanced by blue skies and white billowing clouds. The only downfall? This season, we are experiencing tornado warnings and for the first time, last night we actually heard actual tornado sirens so we had to head towards shelter. Sure enough, you would have found me in my bathtub clutching my littlest dog along with my purse and a few pillows. My big dog wanted nothing to do with the bathroom and remained in the livingroom, nervous and barking, nervous about the odd circumstances. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hail which fell all bout the ground. After the storm the road literally was steaming from the change of temperature. We went from 92 to 75 in a matter of minutes. The hail immediately melted when it hit the hot pavement. As I looked up towards the clearing skies, the sun came out and it started to rain. A double rainbow apparated. I ran into the house and grabbed my camera. Quickly snapped pictures to share with my Facebook friends and family. They were in awe, as was I. The streets remained quiet for another hour, before some people finally came home from wherever they were when the thunderstorm hit. Then it was business as usual, mom’s and children outside as dinner cooked. Such a friendly neighborhood for this gal who has recently moved form NH to NC. I adore the southern accent that people speak with. I have a two bedroom and two bath apartment, as does everyone. Though all the houses look the same on the outside, not all of the apartments are the same on the inside. Some are actually quite tiny. It doesn’t make sense to me. I love to walk along the biggest field behind where I live and mosey down to the pond that is not made for swimming. I have seen deer and in the morning you can hear the giant bullfrog singing his song. It is a fantastic place to live just forty minutes outside the city of Charlotte. Each morning is welcomed by the sound of roosters crowing from the surrounding farms. It is rather like living in a small community village of it’s own. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm that you can hear braying in the evening to let us know he is there. I was lucky to find this gem of a neighborhood.
Well, considering that I’ve been here for about 10 years, I guess I can share what I know. First off, I was pretty sad when I first came to my neighborhood. I came from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I’m not going to lie, I cried, because I missed them and I loved them.. but my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we moved to a better location for housing, a better high school, everything was considered “not ghetto” when we moved to our new neighborhood. Throughout the years, I got used to it, and made some new friends, and some new enemies too in school. I never really truly got to know my neighbors throughout the years, except Mr. Glen and his children, as well as Dennis for a bit, both being right next to us. They have been enjoyable people that I almost can consider as family in some ways, and I truly do appreciate them. I remember when me, mom, dad, and my sister went to Mr. Glen’s wedding (They got re-married) It was really fun and enjoyable to say the least, and something I’m looking forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a Queen. When Mr. Glen’s wife, Ms. Veda, took off the white little strap on her leg and threw it, I caught it! Sadly I didn’t catch the flowers! We all danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven’t seen her since though. I hope she’s moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I’ve only went so far, and that is when I’ve hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games alot, and just enjoy life to the fullest as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I’ll also bring some sticks that I bought from home depot and just practice my balance, And bring my bokken wooden sword if I can,. I have fun enjoying what I love to do. There’s also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven’t played tennis or basketball in a long time, It’s still nice to have in case I ever want to pick it back up and give it another go. My dad grew me and my best friend up on Tennis with Mr. Graves, and we’d always have a great time.. They worked us hard! But we always had fun. I guess there’s a lot of times I’ve had fun in this neighborhood, and there’s plenty of stories, but these are what really stuck out to me, and I believe that the best, is yet to come!
My neighborhood is a quaint little town. It doesn't stand out from any other in South Carolina, but it's got a significant impact on the agriculture sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, something that the town proudly boasts about on the welcoming sign. It's primarily composed of farmland dominated by either peach trees or cattle. Houses that aren't located within the main part of town are widely spaced apart; most are two stories with either metal roofs to help combat the blazing summer heat or gray shingles. More often than not these houses aren't located near the road, but are further back allowing for the front fields to be used for animals/crops. Within the main part of town, there's a single stop light that hangs at a four way. Here is where the only stores in the entire town are located. There are three places in which you can get "fast food': Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, however it closed down a short time ago. There is a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug; funnily enough, they're best known for the Cherry Coca-Cola they sell. There is a small, but expensive grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, more commonly known as IGA. While it is the only grocery store in the entire town, many individuals only stop to pick up one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville in order to purchase the majority of their groceries. The most popular store in the entire town is Dollar General; this store sells a vast array of everyday items and it often busy from the moment it opens until closing time! There is a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman who is well-known within the community. The store has been in Johnston for a plethora of years and even employs two movers who will deliver the purchased furniture! Attached to the furniture store building is a small pet groomers called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They provide a multitude of services such as daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, bathing, etc. Both a doctor's and veterinary practice are situated away from the primary part of town; they are both very small practices, though well-equipped to aid the residents of Johnston. There is a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School. Once students have completed fifth grade, they must attend both middle and high school in the next town over. There are technically no parks within the town, however they are currently in the midst of creating a 2.5 acre recreational area in order to provide families with more opportunities to enjoy outings and attract more visitors/potential residents. Admittedly there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hang out" spots, playgrounds for children, areas to walk pets, or a large variety of restaurants. Despite this it's a nice town, so small that you could pass in the blink of an eye without realizing!
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we tend to take note of it. Some of the neighbors go walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you would expect from that. We are at home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us, Myself and my Wife, and two Daughters ages eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say that everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We get outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Once in a while we grill outside on our back deck and it's always a pleasant smell from the barbecue and all. It seems that there's always someone cutting grass around here and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March through about October, when the grass finally stops growing. We have a lot of trees in our neighborhood as it was originally a wooded area, so there's lots of shade, but there's always a lot of leaves in the Fall as well. So, that means raking and burning the leaves on a yearly basis. I like the smell of burning leaves too, so that's always a nice sign that Fall has arrived. Lately, we've not been having much Winter to speak of, so it just feels like a long Fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door of our house unless someone knocks on the door, which is rare. I like to work in the garage on my truck or other projects from time to time and when I have the garage doors open, it feels like I'm more tuned into the neighborhood. On holidays it is pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving sees some of the neighborhood families visiting with people from out of town and there are extra cars parked everywhere during that time of year. It's the same at other holidays like Mother's day and Christmas. All in all, I like living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.
My neighborhood is in the smack middle of the high desert, where there is dirt, dirt and more dirt. Unless someone has actually experienced living here, they probably donâ€™t really understand the feeling of always seeing brown , and when you do see a lawn, you know that person is spending a fortune on lawn care. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were spread out far and wide. Now it is pretty much the same way by there are a lot of new additions. Honestly this place looks more and more like a city everyday, but supposed most places are changing the same way. Most of the time the people are very friendly, but just like any city you have your good parts and bad. In my neighborhood I'm surrounded by friendly old people iI guess it's a nicer neighborhood. The stores in this place are pretty much the store who have chains, like food for less and smart and final. If you want uscale you have to travel I never really see any whole foods or stores of that nature. The jobs that are most prominent in my city I would say not based on any official demographics, is construction. I think this is on account of this city is still not very developed, there is still a lot of wide open spaces to build. That kind of scares me, I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not keen on going back. Speaking of construction this was the field my full time job is located in, i am a drywall and T-bar instalator. What I like about my home is the different animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, not the least of which is the stark beauty of the desert itself. High desert climate and topography have created challenging ecosystems which need protecting and which are home to different types of wildlife. Human residents of the high desert should take the time to learn about the non-human residents who share this environment in order to co-exist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted very well to the wildlife. I have three children and they are all obsessed with lizards and dessert bugs, as I am writing this now they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As far as attractions goes we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert. It can generate a different experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun the Victorville way. Pop by the nearby Wrightwood to see the snow covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to finish out your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the development of society and industry of Victorville.
When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'm sure that my answer is somewhat unique. While others who respond to this are most likely homeowners with their own individual lives, my situation is a tad bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus that I stay on, and the people that live in my dormitory to be my community. I also consider the surrounding campus to be my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some commonalities with the more conventional ideas about a neighborhood. Just like any conventional neighborhood, the neighborhood I stay in has houses, people, stores and parks. Let us begin by discussing the "houses" that comprise my neighborhood. Before I begin to explore the houses in my neighborhood, it would be best to clarify the types of house that can be found in my neighborhood. There are three types of housing in my immediate vicinity, the apartments, the actual houses, and the dormitory houses. First, In the apartments, there are usually between 2-4 people in any given room, and there are about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type can house about 2 floors, so on average, there are 20 or so people living in each building. Second, are the actual houses that are available for anyone with an affiliation to the school to rent. Typically these are 2-4 bedroom setups that usually have alumni living in them. However, there are only a handful of these types of houses spread throughout the neighborhood, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms which house 100's of students.
